"SECTION 1. FINDINGS."

Summarized: Section 1 presents the findings. The Congress finds that HIV/AIDS is predicted to become the worst infectious disease epidemic in history, surpassing past pandemics like the bubonic plague and the 1918 influenza outbreak. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is widening, potentially increasing child mortality by over 100% in heavily affected regions by 2010. The number of AIDS orphans worldwide is expected to triple in the next decade at current infection rates. The National Intelligence Council predicts a dramatic increase in the number of AIDS orphans worldwide, potentially tripling in the next 10 years. This could lead to economic decay, social fragmentation, and political destabilization in volatile societies. The economic costs of infectious diseases, especially HIV/AIDS, could reduce gross domestic product by 20% or more in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. Despite discouraging statistics, some developing nations have successfully implemented prevention programs to curb HIV infection rates. The economic costs of infectious diseases, especially HIV/AIDS, could reduce gross domestic product by 20% or more in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. Some developing nations like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have successfully implemented prevention programs to curb HIV infection rates. United States financial support for medical research, education, and disease containment as a global strategy has enormous benefits for all Americans. A contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria would be a significant step in combating this epidemic. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund has not been endorsed despite international community support in September 1997. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund, endorsed by the international community in September 1997, has not been implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. Approval by the United States would enable the allocation of Special Drawing Rights. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria leverages resources from donor nations to combat the epidemic. The United States, with 17.16 percent voting power at the IMF, could receive Special Drawing Rights. The Global Fund leverages resources from donor nations to combat HIV/AIDS crisis. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to accept the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The United States Governor of the Fund accepts the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The Secretary of the Treasury will seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights and provide contributions in fiscal years 2004 through 2006. The Secretary of the Treasury will contribute \1/3\ of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Additionally, negotiations will be pursued to encourage other Fund members to make similar contributions.
